author: By Ben Dooley and Hikari Hida
title: As Japan’s Abe Leaves, ‘Abenomics’ Will Remain, for Good or Ill
description: The departing prime minister’s policies helped shake Japan out of decades of stagnation. But long-term restructuring efforts are needed to keep its economy charging forward.
content: TOKYO — Komaki Fujii opened her central Tokyo vegetarian restaurant in 2013, when the future looked bright. Shinzo Abe, Japan’s prime minister, had just taken office promising a bold package of reforms that would supercharge the country’s stagnant economy and transform the way it did business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift’s Dominant ‘Folklore’ Notches a Fifth Week at No. 1
description: The last album to reign this many consecutive weeks was Drake’s “Scorpion” in 2018.
content: In a taped speech for the MTV Video Music Awards on Sunday night, accepting the best direction prize for her gender-switch video “The Man” from her 2019 album, “Lover,” Taylor Swift took a moment to recognize her fans’ support of her latest LP.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Hawk. Lizard. Mole. Human.
description: Because William Blake was right: Every living thing is holy.
content: One of my sons noticed it before the rest of us did: a hawk perched on the edge of the birdbath mounted to our deck rail, only a few feet from the back door. One great yellow claw gripped the edge of the shallow bowl; the other claw was curled up and tucked into the bird’s breast feathers as though for sleep. It was the middle of a bright Sunday afternoon, but the hawk had settled in for a stay. Its coloring — the brown streaking, the pale eyes — indicated a young Cooper’s hawk, not long out of the nest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tell Us How College Is Different This Year
description: We know the coronavirus has changed … everything. We’d love to hear some details about your first weeks back.
content: This is sure to be a strange semester. If you’re at home, on campus or even in a collab house, we’d love to hear from you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: I’m Still Reading Andrew Sullivan. But I Can’t Defend Him.
description: He’s one of the most influential journalists of the last three decades, but he’s shadowed by a 1994 magazine cover story that claimed to show a link between race and I.Q.
content: PROVINCETOWN, Mass. — The only restaurant open late on this sandy tip of Cape Cod is Spiritus Pizza, and men have long gathered on the mottled bricks in front to hang out, gossip and cruise. One night last week, some were blasting disco onto Commercial Street when a slightly stoned Englishman with a salt-and-pepper beard approached them and demanded politely but forcefully that they turn it down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Thomas Kaplan
title: Twitter flags a video shared by Steve Scalise that manipulated Ady Barkan’s interview with Biden.
description: Representative Steve Scalise, the second-ranking House Republican, replaced a video that Twitter flagged as having been manipulated because the words of a progressive activist who was questioning Joseph R. Biden Jr. on his stance on defunding the police were misleadingly grafted together.
content: Representative Steve Scalise, the second-ranking House Republican, replaced a video that Twitter flagged as having been manipulated because the words of a progressive activist who was questioning Joseph R. Biden Jr. on his stance on defunding the police were misleadingly grafted together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Biden Confronts Trump on Safety: ‘He Can’t Stop the Violence’
description: In a blistering speech, Joe Biden charged that crises “have kept multiplying” under President Trump’s watch. It was an effort to refocus the spotlight on the incumbent after a week of Republican attacks.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Monday issued a forceful rebuttal to President Trump’s claim that the former vice president would preside over a nation overwhelmed by disorder and lawlessness, asserting that it was Mr. Trump who had made the country unsafe through his erratic and incendiary governing style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Sudan Signs Peace Deal With Rebel Alliance
description: After years of bloodshed, the country’s transitional government reached an agreement with most but not all of the groups fighting in Darfur and elsewhere.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Hoping to put an end to nearly two decades of bloodshed that has left hundreds of thousands dead and millions more displaced, the transitional government of Sudan signed a peace agreement with an alliance of rebel groups on Monday to end fighting in Darfur and the southern regions of South Kordofan and the Blue Nile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: The wheels come off the school bus industry
description: And students in Britain and New Jersey are facing a particularly uncertain start to the year.
content: School buses are the nation’s largest single form of mass transportation. But during the coronavirus pandemic, the C.D.C. recommends they operate at reduced capacity to allow for social distancing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus Westberg
title: A Virtual Tour of Malawi, the ‘Warm Heart of Africa’
description: Malawi leaves a lasting impression not because of its location or aesthetics, but because of its people, writes the photographer Marcus Westberg.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Marcus Westberg shares a collection of images from Malawi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Mechling
title: This School Year, Unleash Your Inner Ms. Frizzle
description: I’m no merry home educator, but I’ll be channeling the “Magic School Bus” captain when my children and I return for round two of remote learning.
content: A few of my mom friends have confided in me that they don’t completely mind living and learning in lockdown. After the requisite acknowledgments about their own relative luck in a world in free fall, they lower their voices and make their confessions. One woman, whose family relocated from downtown Manhattan to a cabin upstate, said that she prefers her new “Little House on The Prairie” life, an opinion borne out by her Instagram account’s steady feed of children romping about the woods, scribbling in notebooks and making crafts out of sticks. Another friend, who contracted the coronavirus not long after school closed last March, told me that she has never been so happy as when she’s had her entire family underfoot. “Call me crazy,” she said, “but I like home-schooling.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Ana Swanson
title: TikTok Deal Faces Complications as U.S. and China Ratchet Up Tit-for-Tat
description: China’s new export rules, which could delay or scuttle a sale of TikTok, have further turned giant companies into pawns in a geopolitical struggle.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — On most days, companies like ByteDance, Microsoft, Walmart and Oracle are considered kings within their fields. But over the weekend, it became increasingly clear that they can also be something else: a set of pawns.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: As China Flexes, Taiwan Revamps Its Military
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 31, 2020.
content: “Groveling will not bring national security.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Learn to Shuck Oysters at Seamore’s
description: The location in Battery Park City offers a 90-minute session with socially distant seating.
content: With so many oyster producers now shipping directly to home addresses, it pays to be schooled in opening them, a worthwhile party trick that requires guidance and equipment. Both are on offer, along with oyster-friendly wine tastings, at Seamore’s in Battery Park City, part of a group of seafood restaurants with locations around New York City. Bucketlisters.com, an organization that works with tours and experiences in several cities, is the partner here. Each 90-minute session, with socially distant seating, includes a dozen East Coast oysters (four varieties) to pry and slurp, and four wines to sample with them. You get to keep the knife and protective glove.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Belarus, Portland Protests, U.K. Schools: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: Trump Books Keep Coming, and Readers Can’t Stop Buying
description: White House memoirs, journalistic exposés, full-throated defenses of the president: Publishers are producing books for every partisan and wondering if the gravy train ends on Election Day.
content: Since it was released in May, the latest book in the Hunger Games series, “The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes,” has sold 1.3 million copies, a home run of a best seller by publishing’s standards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Frustrated by Election Boycott, Venezuela’s Leader Pardons 100 Opponents
description: President Nicolás Maduro cast his decree as a bid for unity, but many members of the political opposition quickly scorned it.
content: MEXICO CITY — The Venezuelan government said Monday it would pardon more than 100 political opponents who had been targeted for prosecution in what would amount to the country’s largest political amnesty in almost a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Conrad
title: A New Book from a Renowned Photographer of Interiors
description: Throughout his career, Simon Watson has brought his unique eye to crumbling castles, monastic apartments and everything in between.
content: In the 1530s, Cardinal Marcello Cervini, the future Pope Marcellus II, bought Castello Cervini, a medieval monastery surrounded by chestnut trees in Tuscany’s Vivo d’Orcia estate. And while Marcellus II passed away just 22 days after ascending to the papacy in 1555, his family has retained the property for four centuries and counting. By the time the photographer Simon Watson visited, in 2002, Marcellus’s descendants Daria Cervini and her siblings had turned the castle into a summer retreat, but many tokens of the family’s past remained, and a portrait of the ill-fated pope in a crimson mozzetta kept watch over all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker, Thomas Kaplan and Shane Goldmacher
title: The Portland shooting amplified tensions in the presidential race.
description: A fatal shooting after clashes in Portland came on the heels of the shooting deaths of two people during confrontations in Kenosha, Wis., earlier in the week.
content: The fatal shooting in Portland, Ore., over the weekend capped a volatile week of street violence that increasingly hangs over the 2020 race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Up on the Roof, Flesh and Blood Dancers Move and Connect
description: A new performance series, Arts on the Roof, affords some of the few opportunities to watch live dance in New York this summer and fall.
content: The dancer Chelsea Ainsworth stood before a small outdoor audience on Friday night, about to perform live for the first time in 25 weeks. Beneath her tap shoe-clad feet was a plywood stage that she and her husband, the visual artist Kyle Netzeband, had spent the past two days constructing by hand. The elevator in their East Village building was broken, so they had to lug materials up six flights of stairs. But that wasn’t going to stop them: They were determined to bring dance to a live audience, on the rooftop where the finished stage now stood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘All or Nothing’ and ‘American Ninja Warrior’
description: An Amazon sports docuseries returns, this time focusing on the soccer club Tottenham Hotspur. And an athletic competition show prepares for a new season with a special event.
content: ALL OR NOTHING: TOTTENHAM HOTSPUR Stream on Amazon. Tottenham Hotspur, an English Premier League soccer club located in North London, endured two major upheavals last season: the replacement of its manager Mauricio Pochettino with José Mourinho, and the suspension of league play because of the coronavirus pandemic. This documentary series provides a peek behind the scenes during these difficult periods. Some fans and commentators were skeptical about the decision to hire Mourinho because his managerial style diverges sharply from Pochettino’s, which was successful for several years. After an inconclusive sixth place finish in July, the jury is still out about the choice. Perhaps this series will give a sense of how the coming season will play out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Joe Biden Had Better Watch It
description: After Trump’s unconventional convention, there is danger for the former vice president all over the political landscape.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I’m dying to hear your take on the Republican convention. Mine in a nutshell: Joe Biden had better watch out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: American Intelligence Knows What Russia Is Doing
description: Congress needs to understand about foreign election meddling, too.
content: The logic offered by the director of national intelligence for restricting in-person briefings for Congress on foreign meddling in the election campaign doesn’t pass the smell test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: In Massachusetts, Markey Outflanks Kennedy by Running as Bold Insurgent
description: Edward Markey, 74, entered Congress before Joseph Kennedy III was born. But in their Senate race he has harnessed the energy of Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and the ascendant left, much to Mr. Kennedy’s frustration.
content: BOSTON — Stepping out of the rain on a dreary Saturday morning, Representative Joseph P. Kennedy III made no attempt to hide his frustration as he raced from neighborhood to neighborhood in a city as synonymous with his family as it is with the Green Monster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh and Hari Kumar
title: Indian Court Hands Down Symbolic Sentence for Outspoken Lawyer
description: The case against Prashant Bhushan, a public interest lawyer who criticized the Supreme Court and its chief justice in tweets, was seen as a test of free expression in the world’s largest democracy.
content: NEW DELHI — India’s Supreme Court on Monday handed down a symbolic sentence —  a fine of about 1 cent — to a prominent lawyer who posted tweets critical of the court and its chief justice.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Runway Lights Failed, So Villagers Used Their Headlights to Aid an Airlift
description: A child was waiting to be flown to Anchorage, but the pilot of a LifeMed Alaska flight could not see the runway at the airport in Igiugig, Alaska, officials said.
content: The plane circled overheard, the pilot searching in the darkness of a far-flung Alaskan village for a runway that didn’t seem to be there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Court Denies Flynn’s Bid to End Case and Renews Fight Over McGahn Subpoena
description: Two cases touching on the Trump-Russia investigation are dividing the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
content: WASHINGTON — A Federal District Court judge may go forward with his plans to scrutinize the Justice Department’s request to drop the prosecution of President Trump’s former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn, a full appeals court ruled on Monday. A three-judge panel on the court had earlier ordered the judge to end the case immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: A Local Alternative to the Big Delivery Apps, in Los Angeles
description: Modeled after food delivery services in Seoul, a tiny Koreatown business keeps neighborhood restaurants running through the pandemic.
content: LOS ANGELES — The busiest time of the day for Vivian Jung is that blur between 11 a.m. and 1 p.m., when the lunch orders just won’t stop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Street Violence Hangs Over the Campaign
description: Killings in Oregon and Wisconsin reverberate in the 2020 race: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: “Law and order” politics take center stage as the protests — and counterprotests — take a deadly turn. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Rush to Polling Judgment
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Four years ago, Donald Trump rallied from a summer deficit in the polls to win the presidency. In the wake of this year’s Republican convention and the continuing chaos in some cities, many people — both his supporters and detractors — seem obsessed with the notion that he will do so again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Battilana
title: 3 Highly Portable Picnic Options That Aren’t Sandwiches
description: Try Italian calzones, Turkish pide or Eastern European piroshki.
content: These days, most of us aren’t hosting dinner parties or meeting friends at our favorite restaurants. We’re greeting friends at the park or on the beach for socially distanced picnics.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Who Replaces Me?’
description: A Black police officer in Flint, Mich., reflects on what it now means to be part of the force in his hometown.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: It’s Just You and Me and the Modem in ‘Here We Are’
description: Theater for One was built on the idea of face-to-face encounters. Moving it online could have been a disaster, but instead it’s a heartbreaker.
content: After my first experience of Theater for One — back in pre-pandemic days, when it meant sharing a small booth with an actor who performed a short play for you — I imagined it as what speed dating would be if you fell in love with everyone you met. Sitting that close to an actor’s face, hearing a story I could not avoid being part of because no one else was there to hear it, I was instantly drawn into the uncanny, enraptured collaboration of theater, with its roots in campfire tales and community bonding and a parent’s hushed voice at bedtime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorie Chevlen
title: How to Help Someone Who Lost Their Job
description: Check in, but not too much.
content: Losing a job is always a dispiriting experience, but losing a job when jobless claims have reached record highs can be especially traumatic. Competition among job seekers is stiffer than ever, and experiencing it during a global pandemic when you can’t even commiserate in person? Even worse. Still, there are ways to reach out to newly unemployed friends from a distance and make the experience slightly less awful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Fans Strife as Unrest Roils the U.S.
description: The president plans to visit to Kenosha, Wis., on Tuesday, unwelcome by officials in a state pivotal to the election, to condemn what he calls “left-wing mobs.”
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump has been throwing accelerant on the fire of the nation’s social unrest rather than trying to put it out, seeking confrontation rather than calm at a volatile moment his advisers hope will help salvage his campaign for a second term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker, Thomas Kaplan and Shane Goldmacher
title: Portland Shooting Amplifies Tensions in Presidential Race
description: A fatal shooting after clashes in Portland came on the heels of the shooting deaths of two people during confrontations in Kenosha, Wis., earlier in the week.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — A fatal shooting in Portland, Ore., over the weekend led President Trump to unleash a torrent of tweets and attacks on Sunday, capping a volatile week of street violence that is becoming a major theme in the final weeks of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: Pranab Mukherjee, Indispensable Man of Indian Politics, Dies at 84
description: A journalist turned politician, he was India’s president from 2012 to 2017 and wore many hats during a career that spanned political generations.
content: Pranab Mukherjee, an Indian politician who rose to high office alongside one of India’s longest-serving prime ministers, Indira Gandhi, died on Monday at a hospital in New Delhi. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: Tomato Season!
description: Take advantage of summer’s bounty with Hetty McKinnon’s herby salad with tamarind and maple, David Tanis’s tomato risotto, or a basic sauce.
content: I am not big on preserving. In fact, I’m not big on spending a lot of time on anything in the kitchen that doesn’t turn out to be dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Sauerbrey
title: Meet Germany’s Bizarre Anti-Lockdown Protesters
description: A strange mix of conspiracy theorists, far-right extremists and ordinary citizens have taken to the streets. Why?
content: They’re out on the streets again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Sameer Yasir and Hari Kumar
title: India and China Face Off Again at Border as Troops Move In
description: After months of efforts to defuse tensions, soldiers rushed to shout in each others’ faces again. Though the confrontation wasn’t bloody, where it happened was significant.
content: NEW DELHI — Indian and Chinese troops have locked horns again along their disputed border, Indian officials said Monday, in a sign that the deadly tensions that erupted in June between the world’s two most populous countries are not going away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: ‘I Miss No One.’ (She’s Kidding. Kind Of.)
description: Elsa Majimbo’s humorous videos about pandemic life have helped her star rise beyond Nairobi.
content: Hundreds of thousands of people want to know two things about Elsa Majimbo. Where did she get her “Matrix”-esque sunglasses? And what kind of chips is she eating?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: In the Massachusetts Senate primary, Markey has outflanked Kennedy by running as a bold insurgent.
description: Representative Joseph P. Kennedy III is trailing Senator Edward J. Markey in every poll ahead of the Democratic Senate primary in Massachusetts on Tuesday, and may become the first Kennedy to lose a race in the state.
content: Representative Joseph P. Kennedy III is trailing Senator Edward J. Markey in every poll ahead of the Democratic Senate primary in Massachusetts on Tuesday, and may become the first Kennedy to lose a race in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: ‘Hotel Rwanda’ Hero, Paul Rusesabagina, Is Held on Terrorism Charge
description: Mr. Rusesabagina sheltered more than 1,200 Rwandans who fled to the hotel he was managing during the 1994 genocide, a story that became a film. But he has become a critic of President Paul Kagame.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Paul Rusesabagina, whose bravery in saving more than 1,200 fellow Rwandans from genocide inspired the film “Hotel Rwanda,” has been arrested by the authorities in Rwanda who are holding him there on charges that include terrorism, arson and murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Curbs on Mongolian Language Teaching Prompt Large Protests in China
description: “Mongolian is our mother language,” the students shouted. Rights activists say the demonstrations are the biggest in the northern region since 2011.
content: Thousands of ethnic Mongolians in northern China have gathered outside schools to protest a new policy that would reduce the teaching of their language in favor of Chinese, according to rights groups, a rare display of mass discontent in the border region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harvey Araton
title: John Thompson’s Success at Georgetown Made Him Ahead of His Time
description: He inspired a generation of young, Black players when their acceptance was not taken for granted. He pushed open doors for plenty of coaches, too.
content: The story, as John Thompson Jr. often shared it, was that he was told by the Georgetown president, upon being hired to coach the university’s moribund men’s basketball program in the spring of 1972, that it would be great if he could win a few games. Maybe even qualify for a slice of postseason affirmation in the National Invitation Tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Big Oil Faded. Will Big Tech?
description: Not that long ago, it was American oil powers — not tech giants — that ruled the economy and influenced world events.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel Goldman
title: Republicans Have Another Option. It’s Not Trumpism.
description: When Republicans jettison liberty as a core political value, they reject conservatism and America itself.
content: Republicans gathered last week for their election pitch, but the convention did not settle a rancorous debate among activists and thinkers about what it means to be conservatives and where they fit in the political world today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: N.Y.C. to Pay $5.9 Million in Death of Transgender Woman at Rikers
description: Layleen Polanco had a fatal epileptic seizure while in isolation, an investigation found, spurring calls to end solitary confinement and close the jail complex.
content: New York City has reached the largest settlement recorded over an inmate’s death at the Rikers Island jail complex, agreeing to pay $5.9 million to the family of a 27-year-old transgender woman who died there last year while in solitary confinement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Family Accuses College of Forcing Ailing Son to Play Football
description: The family of a University of New Mexico football player who killed himself in November has sued the university, the former football coach and the N.C.A.A.
content: As the University of New Mexico football team endured another losing season last fall, Nahje Flowers, a defensive lineman, began complaining to friends and counselors about his coaches forcing him to play, even though he had injuries, severe headaches and depression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Joe Ruby, a Creator of ‘Scooby-Doo,’ Is Dead at 87
description: Charged with creating an animated mystery series, Mr. Ruby and his writing partner, Ken Spears, came up with a show that endures more than 50 years later.
content: “Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!” the ghostly, goofy animated mystery series featuring a ragtag quartet of teenage sleuths and a cowardly Great Dane with a gruff bark who leads the gang in and out of trouble, was a hit from its first episode in 1969.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Myriam Sarachik Never Gave Up on Physics
description: The New York-based scientist overcame sexism and personal tragedy to make major contributions to the field, for which she received recognition this year.
content: In 1963, Myriam P. Sarachik tackled a big question in her field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Campus outbreaks are beginning to infect surrounding communities.
content: Outbreaks at colleges across the United States are beginning to spill off campus and infect surrounding communities — a worrisome trend that does not bode well for other school reopenings this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Robin Montgomery, Still Just 15, Was Ready for Her U.S. Open Debut
description: Coming out of the sport’s shutdown, the wild card entry hoped her preparation would surprise people.
content: As she sat in a small interview room in Melbourne this January, Robin Montgomery could see that her dreams were more within reach than ever before. Nearby on the grounds of the Australian Open, another 15-year-old, Coco Gauff, was playing in the fourth round against the eventual champion Sofia Kenin, having beaten Naomi Osaka, the defending champion, a round earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trump Had One Good Response to Covid-19. His Party Killed It.
description: Aid to the unemployed saved us from disaster. Now it’s gone.
content: For the most part, America under Donald Trump’s leadership has offered an object lesson in how not to handle a pandemic. Delay and denial deprived us of any chance of containing the coronavirus’s early spread; impatience and further denial led to a huge second wave of infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
title: Israel and Hamas Agree to Cool Hostilities, for Now
description: With the coronavirus spreading fast in Gaza, the sides agreed to stop bombarding each other, and Israel said it would resume fuel supplies. A cash infusion from Qatar helped seal the deal.
content: JERUSALEM — With the coronavirus spreading fast through the Gaza Strip, the Palestinian militant group Hamas agreed Monday night to cool its latest round of hostilities with Israel in exchange for a cash infusion from Qatar and for Israel’s agreement to let fuel flow back to Gaza’s power station, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: China’s exports, Mongolia protests, Indian Supreme Court: Here’s what you need to know.
content: This was supposed to be the year that China’s export machine began to stall, given Trump administration tariffs on Chinese goods, factories shut down by the coronavirus crisis and countries pushing companies to shift their logistics elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Midwest Sees a Spike as Covid-19 Cases Decline Elsewhere
description: In nine U.S. states, case numbers are still rising or setting records. The virus is pummeling the economies of India and South Korea. Hong Kong began a Beijing-backed testing program.
content: Reports of new cases have fallen significantly around the country since July; they are now flat in 26 states and falling in 15 others. But in nine states, cases are still growing, and in some, setting records — especially in the Midwest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Dizziness Upon Standing Can Lead to Falls and Fractures
description: The problem, a brief but precipitous drop in blood pressure that causes lightheadedness or dizziness when standing up, is called orthostatic hypotension.
content: Orthostatic hypotension — to many people those are unfamiliar words for a relatively common but often unrecognized medical problem that can have devastating consequences, especially for older adults. It refers to a brief but precipitous drop in blood pressure that causes lightheadedness or dizziness when standing up after lying down or sitting, and sometimes even after standing, for a prolonged period.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: Youth and Experience Will Face Off in the U.S. Open Women’s Draw
description: The No. 1 and No. 2 players are absent, but Serena Williams continues her quest for a record title, while Sofia Kenin and Naomi Osaka are at her heels.
content: The women’s singles draw has been depleted by many absences; six of the top 10 women will not be playing in this year’s U.S. Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Kurczy
title: Aldir Blanc, Lyricist Who Pushed Samba’s Boundaries, Dies at 73
description: His songs included “O Bêbado e a Equilibrista,” a popular call for the amnesty of political exiles during Brazil’s military dictatorship. He died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: An advocacy group’s ‘Unbossed Women’s Agenda’ would help Black domestic workers.
description: A project from the National Domestic Workers Alliance called the We Dream in Black initiative on Monday morning released its “Unbossed Women’s Agenda,” which outlines economic and social policies that aim to transform domestic work and infrastructure to support not only Black domestic workers, but also their communities.
content: A project from the National Domestic Workers Alliance called the We Dream in Black initiative on Monday morning released its “Unbossed Women’s Agenda,” which outlines economic and social policies that aim to transform domestic work and infrastructure to support not only Black domestic workers, but also their communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Documentary on Women in the Restaurant Business
description: The 29-minute film follows three professionals as they manage working in male-dominated spaces.
content: To highlight the challenges women face in the restaurant business, not just as chefs but also as owners and in jobs like butchers, KitchenAid, the kitchen appliance company, has commissioned “A Woman’s Place,” a documentary by Rayka Zehtabchi and produced by Digitas, Ventureland and Vox Creative. The 29-minute film follows Karyn Tomlinson, a Minneapolis chef; Marielle Fabie, the chef de cuisine at a ramen shop in Oakland, Calif.; and Etana Diaz, a butcher from Seattle, as they manage working in male-dominated spaces, contend with their parents’ aspirations for them and try to meet their personal goals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: At the V.M.A.s, Lady Gaga’s Clothes Were Good, but Her Masks Were Better
description: This is one way to use the red carpet and fashion to send a message.
content: The question of what the red carpet, that weird celebrity style ritual that reached its apogee in the early 21st century as a marketing/social media/fashion Frankenstein’s monster, would become in a Covid-19 world — could it still exist at all, when most people have given up on party dressing entirely — was finally answered Sunday night at, of all places, the 2020 MTV Video Music Awards. And it was answered by Lady Gaga.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: E.P.A. Relaxes Rules Limiting Toxic Waste From Coal Plants
description: The agency weakened Obama-era rules meant to keep metals and other pollution out of rivers and streams, saving industry tens of millions of dollars.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Monday relaxed strict Obama-era standards for how coal-fired power plants dispose of wastewater laced with dangerous pollutants like lead, selenium and arsenic, a move environmental groups said would leave rivers and streams vulnerable to toxic contamination.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Aug. 31, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 31, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 31, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Attach an Asterisk to This U.S. Open? Tennis History Mocks That Idea
description: The field is considerably diminished because of complications related to the pandemic, but our columnist can tell you about many other Grand Slam draws that lacked the best players of the day.
content: The United States Open that is set to begin in New York on Monday will be far from full strength, extraordinarily far, but will it really be the Asterisk Open?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Trump’s Tariffs? Coronavirus? China’s Exports Are Surging Anyway
description: Chinese companies account for a greater share of goods sold abroad, showing their tremendous strength despite mounting challenges.
content: ZHONGSHAN, China — This was supposed to be the year that China’s export machine began to stall. President Trump had imposed broad tariffs on Chinese goods. Countries like Japan and France pushed companies to shift production from China. The pandemic had crippled China’s factories by the end of January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Eye on Beirut, Senegal Port Rushes to Truck Away Tons of Ammonium Nitrate
description: After nearly 3,000 tons of ammonium nitrate caused a devastating explosion in Beirut, Lebanon, the West African nation of Senegal discovered the same amount sitting in its port in Dakar.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — At Dakar’s congested port last week, men in neon orange and yellow jackets waved their arms to speed up a line of trucks carrying away sacks of ammonium nitrate — the compound that exploded at the port in Beirut, Lebanon, three weeks before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry and Hiroko Masuike
title: Joe Biden, Child Virus Cases, U.S. Open: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah, Johnny Diaz, Christina Morales and Bryan Pietsch
title: ‘Bill & Ted’ Explained by Gen X to Gen Z
description: For many members of a certain generation, “Bill & Ted’s Excellent Adventure” and its sequel were excellent, seminal works. For members of a younger generation … what?
content: In 1989, two teenagers used a magic telephone booth to travel through time to finish a school project. For many people around their age, the movie about those teenagers, Bill S. Preston Esq. and Ted “Theodore” Logan, enshrined them in pop culture history: excellent avatars for a generation of affable, shaggy slackers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harold Varmus and Rajiv Shah
title: It Has Come to This: Ignore the C.D.C.
description: The agency’s new guidelines are wrong, so states have to step up on their own to suppress the coronavirus.
content: We were startled and dismayed last week to learn that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in a perplexing series of statements, had altered its testing guidelines to reduce the testing of asymptomatic people for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: 5 Standout Recipes From Julia Reed, an Irreverent Voice of the South
description: The journalist, who died last week at 59, mixed sophistication and down-home pleasures in her cooking.
content: Julia Reed, the Southern journalist who died of cancer on Friday at 59, cooked very much the way she lived. Which is to say, she was really into it. Both her appetite and her writing reflected a bawdy sophistication wrapped in a very pretty Southern shawl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart and Alan Rappeport
title: The pandemic will define the Treasury secretary’s legacy, for better or for worse.
description: When the pandemic hit, the task of saving the economy was an opportunity for Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin to transform himself from an unremarkable Treasury secretary into a national hero.
content: When the pandemic hit, the task of saving the economy was an opportunity for Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin to transform himself from an unremarkable Treasury secretary into a national hero.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: A Vow of Silence, a Cabin in the Woods, a Terrible Wildfire
description: If anyone could outsmart a wildfire, it would seem to be Tad Jones, who lived for decades in a California forest, more a friend of nature than of man.
content: LAST CHANCE, Calif. — Even for Last Chance, a rugged community in the forests above the Pacific Ocean where residents mill their own lumber and grow their own food, Tad Jones was particularly ascetic. He shunned electricity and plumbing. He once spent a year living in the hollow base of a redwood tree. For decades he took a vow of silence, scrawling in notebooks or on a tiny chalkboard when he had something to say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: House Panel to Subpoena DeJoy Over Mail Delays and Trump Communications
description: The chairwoman of the House Oversight Committee said the postmaster general had withheld requested documents, telling her panel his verbal testimony should suffice.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, Democrat of New York and the chairwoman of the House Oversight Committee, said Monday that she would subpoena Louis DeJoy, the postmaster general, for documents she said he had withheld from Congress related to mail delays and communications with the Trump campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: With Some Big Names Missing, U.S. Open Men’s Draw Still Looks Strong
description: Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal won’t be in Queens, but up-and-coming stars like Dominic Thiem and Daniil Medvedev will pose a challenge to Novak Djokovic.
content: As a majority of the world’s best tennis players gather in Flushing Meadows once again, there are some friendly faces we’ll be missing. Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, two of the Big Three, will not be participating, among others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Trying Again: A Plan for Reopening California
description: Monday: Here’s what you need to know about California’s second big reopening plan. Also: Eviction legislation; and Chadwick Boseman.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Far Right Germans Try to Storm Reichstag as Virus Protests Escalate
description: Germany has handled the pandemic well and its government enjoys high public trust. But the minority opposing coronavirus rules includes a far-right faction that worries officials.
content: BERLIN — It was shortly after 7 p.m. when a self-described healer got on stage outside the German Parliament and urged the jeering crowd of protesters to storm the building: “There is no more police!” she shouted. “We have won!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: A Teacher and Congresswoman Confronts School Reopenings
description: Representative Jahana Hayes, a former National Teacher of the Year, says that she has many concerns — and that parents need to make their voices heard.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Reid Epstein. Lisa is off this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerrelle Guy
title: A Plum Crumble That Meets You Where You Are
description: Look to those graham crackers in the back of your cupboard, and put them to use in this simple dessert.
content: It’s hard to find the charm in something new when every day can bring unpleasant surprises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: The Few, the Proud, the White: The Marine Corps Balks at Promoting Generals of Color
description: A respected, combat-tested Black colonel has been passed over three times for promotion to brigadier general. What does his fate say about the Corps?
content: WASHINGTON — All things being equal, Col. Anthony Henderson has the military background that the Marine Corps says it prizes in a general: multiple combat tours, leadership experience and the respect of those he commanded and most who commanded him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Who the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
content: The entry THEA has appeared 73 times in the New York Times Crossword, clued as a variety of people with that name. In addition, it has been clued as a two-word entry, such as the TV show, “THE A-Team,” and the jazz classic, “Take THE A Train.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Suburban Home Sales Boom as People Move Out of N.Y.C.
description: Buyers worried about the health risks of living in packed urban neighborhoods seek the space and land  the city  can't provide.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Theaters are testing whether Americans are ready to return to the movies.
description: Theater executives are betting that a Covid-19 vaccine will arrive and that studios will soon return to their decades-old system of releasing movies. “There is significant pent-up demand” for the theater experience, one executive said.
content: Theater executives are betting that a Covid-19 vaccine will arrive and that studios will soon return to their decades-old system of releasing movies. “There is significant pent-up demand” for the theater experience, one executive said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: Federal Government Relaxes Rules on Feeding Low-Income Students
description: Under pressure from Congress, the Agriculture Department agreed to extend special rules making it easier for schools to provide subsidized meals, but only through December.
content: The Agriculture Department, under pressure from Congress and officials in school districts across the country, said on Monday that it would allow schools to provide free breakfast and lunch to any child or teenager through the end of 2020, provided funding lasts. Advocates for the poor hailed the announcement as an important step to ensure that more needy children are fed during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Chocolate and Art from Mast and the Met
description: The Mount Kisco, N.Y., company teamed up with the Metropolitan Museum to create a special assortment of bars as fund-raisers.
content: Mast, the chocolate makers originally based in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, but now in Mount Kisco, N.Y., teamed up with the Metropolitan Museum of Art two years ago to create a special assortment of bars for the gift shop, each wrapped in paintings from the Met. Some are notably well matched, like Katsushika Hokusai’s “Under the Wave Off Kanagawa” for a bar of sea salt chocolate, and John Singer Sargent’s “Madame X” with dark chocolate. As a fund-raiser for its 150th anniversary, the collection of chocolate bars in a dozen flavors will benefit the museum. For each $9 bar, $5.50 will go to the Met; for the $100 set, $60 is donated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Coco Gauff Loses in the First Round of the U.S. Open
description: Gauff double faulted often and had her serve broken seven times by Anastasija Sevastova.
content: With no roar from the fans, all that was left on Monday for Coco Gauff was the roar of the planes as they passed over the all-but-empty Louis Armstrong Stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Drone Delivery? Amazon Moves Closer With F.A.A. Approval
description: The agency said it had issued a certificate clearing the way for the company to use drones to fly packages to its customers’ doorsteps.
content: Amazon has received federal approval to use drones to deliver packages, bringing the retailer a critical step closer to its goal of shortening delivery times to 30 minutes or less.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
title: A shift on election briefings to Congress could create an information gap for voters.
description: The elimination of in-person election security briefings to Congress could leave the public with a diminished understanding of the threats facing the election as it enters a critical phase.
content: The decision by the nation’s top intelligence official to halt classified, in-person briefings to Congress about foreign interference in a presidential election that is just nine weeks away exposes the fundamental tension about who needs to know this information: just the president, or the voters whose election infrastructure, and minds, are the target of the hacking?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1 Million Homes in California
description: A hillside house in Oakland, a midcentury-modern home built by Joseph Eichler in Los Angeles and a one-bedroom cottage in Laguna Beach.
content: Many of the houses in this neighborhood, known as Merriewood, are cottages built in the 1920s as vacation homes for city residents. The owner of this house, who bought it in 2012, updated the kitchen and bathrooms and added a shed, used as a home office, to the upstairs deck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Liberty Will Investigate University’s Operations Under Jerry Falwell Jr.
description: The board of trustees said an independent forensic firm would look into all facets of Liberty’s operations, including “financial, real estate and legal matters,” while Mr. Falwell was president.
content: The board of trustees of Liberty University announced on Monday that it had retained an independent forensic firm to conduct an investigation into the school’s operations under Jerry Falwell Jr., who resigned last week in the wake of a sex scandal after serving as its president and chancellor since 2007.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: China Detains Australian Host for Chinese State TV
description: The detention of Cheng Lei, who has long appeared on business programs for China’s international broadcaster, could add to tensions between Australia and China.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — Investigators in China have detained an Australian journalist who has been a host on Chinese state-run television, the Australian foreign ministry said on Monday, opening up another potential point of friction in testy relations between the two countries.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Steven Cohen’s Redemption Tour
description: The billionaire hedge fund manager is in talks to buy the New York Mets at a pivotal moment for the sports business — and his reputation.
content: Want this delievered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: The Bizarro 2020 U.S. Open Begins
description: If a Grand Slam tournament happens and there are not 50,000 daily spectators there to watch it, is it really a scene? The players are making it one.
content: The four biggest tournaments in tennis, known as the Grand Slams, so clearly reflect the cities in which they take place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: After Contact Tracing, Some U.S. Open Players Are Put on Tighter Restrictions
description: These athletes did not test positive for the coronavirus themselves, but they had close contact with an infected athlete who has been withdrawn from the tournament.
content: You might think Kristina Mladenovic would have been nothing but delighted on Monday after winning her first match in the first Grand Slam tennis tournament since the coronavirus pandemic disrupted tennis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: At the U.S. Open, Doubles, of All Things, Stays Stable
description: Juan Sebastián Cabal and Robert Farah return to defend their titles, as do Timea Babos and Kristina Mladenovic, in two packed and experienced doubles draws.
content: The men’s and women’s doubles draws at the United States Open this year are stacked with former Grand Slam doubles champions as well as new and exciting partnerships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: An Inviting Brooklyn Tasting Room for New York Wines
description: Hound’s Tree of Mattituck, N.Y., has a selection of more than 80 wines all from New York State.
content: Hound’s Tree of Mattituck, N.Y., in Long Island’s North Fork wine country, has opened an inviting tasting room attached to its new working winery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It’s worth a visit, even if it means sipping socially distanced outdoors, for one of the best New York State and especially Long Island wine lists you’re likely to find, with a selection of more than 80 in a vast range of varietals and styles. About a quarter of the wines are made from grapes cultivated on Hound’s Tree’s own 30-acre estate, established five years ago by Alex Rosanelli, a winemaking aficionado from New York who is on track to become a master sommelier. His approach is a minimal-intervention style. For now the wines have been made by another company on the North Fork but will soon be produced in the Brooklyn location. To accompany the wines served by the taste, glass and bottle, there are oysters, small plates, charcuterie and cheeses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg, Christopher Clarey, Matt Futterman and Max Gendler
title: 2020 U.S. Open: Highlights From Day 1
description: Novak Djokovic and Naomi Osaka won their first round matches. Coco Gauff lost. And the pandemic-era atmosphere was decidedly bizarre.
content: Naomi Osaka, who withdrew from the Saturday final of the Western & Southern Open with a hamstring injury, prevailed in the last match at Arthur Ashe Stadium on Monday night, beating Misaki Doi 6-2, 5-7, 6-2.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Girl in Taiwan Is Swept High by a Kite
description: Powerful winds swept a 3-year-old girl into the sky after she became entangled in the kite’s tail during a festival in Taiwan. The girl landed safely.
content: HONG KONG — A 3-year-old girl was swept high into the sky after a streamer became tangled around her neck during a kite-flying festival in northern Taiwan this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nell Freudenberger
title: In Yaa Gyasi’s New Novel, a Young Scientist Tries to Understand Her Family’s Pain
description: “Transcendent Kingdom,” by the author of “Homegoing,” features a Stanford Ph.D. student struggling to comprehend the addiction that killed her brother.
content: TRANSCENDENT KINGDOMBy Yaa Gyasi288 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $27.95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Lebanon Taps a New Prime Minister Amid Swirling Crises
description: The country’s president has designated a diplomat, Mustafa Adib, to form a government that must address an economic meltdown and the aftermath of the Beirut explosion.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A little-known diplomat was designated as Lebanon’s next prime minister on Monday through a rushed process aimed at showing official progress in addressing the country’s many crises since a massive explosion destroyed parts of Beirut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Singing Dogs Re-emerge From Extinction for Another Tune
description: The animal was believed to have disappeared from the highlands of New Guinea, but was found on the island’s Indonesian side.
content: The New Guinea Singing Dog, a dingo-like animal with a unique howling style, was considered extinct in the wild. But scientists reported Monday that the dogs live on, based on DNA collected by an intrepid and indefatigable field researcher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and William K. Rashbaum
title: In Steve Bannon Case, Prosecutors Have ‘Voluminous’ Emails
description: The documents were seized in a case against the president’s former aide, who is accused along with three others of a fraudulent scheme to build a border wall, prosecutors said.
content: Federal prosecutors have seized “voluminous” emails and other communications in their case against Stephen K. Bannon, the former adviser to President Trump who is charged with defrauding donors to a private group that promised to build a wall on the Mexican border, the government said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Associated Press
title: Jon Rahm Sinks a Big Putt to Win Playoff at the BMW Championship
description: Dustin Johnson, the third-round leader, forced the playoff with Rahm, who shut the door by sinking a putt of over 65 feet for a birdie 3 on the first extra hole.
content: OLYMPIA FIELDS, Ill. — Even with so few people around, Jon Rahm could hear from the other side of the Olympia Fields clubhouse that Dustin Johnson had made a 45-foot birdie on the final hole to force a playoff on Sunday in the BMW Championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: John Thompson, Hall of Fame Basketball Coach, Dies at 78
description: The first Black coach to lead a team to the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball championship, he helped mold N.B.A. stars like Patrick Ewing and Allen Iverson at Georgetown University.
content: John Thompson Jr., the Hall of Fame basketball coach who led Georgetown University to national collegiate prominence and became the first African-American coach to take a team to the N.C.A.A. basketball championship, died on Sunday. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Padres Bulk Up and Set Their Sights on Catching the Dodgers
description: San Diego dealt 16 players and acquired nine major leaguers in a rush of deals before Monday’s trading deadline, hoping to challenge the perennial division favorites in Los Angeles.
content: As he canvassed the major leagues before Monday’s trading deadline, A.J. Preller even spoke with Andrew Friedman, his chief rival in the National League West. Friedman runs baseball operations for the Los Angeles Dodgers, the team that has it all. Preller is the general manager of the San Diego Padres, their historically hapless neighbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What We Learned From the D.N.C.
description: After the convention ended, a panel of Times political journalists who analyzed the Democrats’ big event discussed the ticket, Joe Biden’s speech and the party’s priorities.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Sigrid Nunez Follows ‘The Friend’ With a Sorrowful, Funny Novel About Death
description: In “What Are You Going Through,” a terminally ill woman (with some resemblance to Susan Sontag) asks a friend to help her end her life.
content: It takes something more than intelligence to be able to write intelligently. It requires something closer to echolocation, an acute sense, in mid-flight, of where you are.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: Helping Children With Pandemic Grief
description: Many children may learn of a grandparent’s death without a chance to visit to say goodbye.
content: Between travel restrictions and limits on visitors to hospitals, parents may get the news of a loved one’s death over the phone and find themselves having to tell children who may be unprepared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: Israeli Airliner Completes First Direct Flight to Arab Emirates
description: The flight carried the hope of closer ties between Israel and the Arab world, and a diplomatic delegation that included President Trump’s son-in-law, Jared Kushner.
content: JERUSALEM — A chartered El Al airliner carrying Israeli and American diplomats landed in the United Arab Emirates at 3:38 p.m. local time on Monday, completing a symbolic first direct flight from Tel Aviv to Abu Dhabi that officials said would pave the way for formal diplomatic and commercial ties and might inspire other Arab nations to follow suit in normalizing relations with the Jewish state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: At the W.N.B.A., the Fight for Racial Justice Goes Way Back
description: “It’s like basketball: Preparation shows, and we’ve been prepared for this moment,” says New York Liberty guard Layshia Clarendon.
content: — Kimberlé Crenshaw, co-founder of the #SayHerName campaign
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Tanier
title: The N.F.L.’s Quarterback Soap Opera in Eight Story Lines
description: This season’s must-watch competitions are traditional (Aaron Rodgers), financial (Dak Prescott) and existential (Cam Newton). Ryan Fitzpatrick, as always, returns in his usual role.
content: The problem with a quarterback competition between Mitch Trubisky and Nick Foles is that the winner will be either Mitch Trubisky or Nick Foles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Mizell
title: Bria Hartley Found the Right Fit With the Phoenix Mercury
description: Hartley, a seventh-year guard, was having a career year for Phoenix before a season-ending injury cut it short. But this year has given her something to build on, even beyond basketball.
content: It takes more than big names to win games in the W.N.B.A. The New York Times is talking to players across the league who are making an impact in their own way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli, Caryn Ganz, Jon Pareles, Ben Sisario and Lindsay Zoladz
title: MTV Video Music Awards: 6 Memorable Moments
description: Lady Gaga transported viewers to “Chromatica” (in a mask) at an event that tried to make a virtual collection of performances and speeches appear like a communal celebration.
content: As late as this month, the 2020 MTV Video Music Awards were still scheduled to be staged in person at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, though little to no audience was expected because of the ongoing pandemic. Instead, the network announced on Aug. 7 that outdoor performances would be “more feasible and safer than an indoor event,” scrapping the central location but forging ahead with a makeshift show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Trump, Vicar of Fear and Violence
description: He continues the old practice of stoking white victimhood for votes.
content: The use of white fear and white victimhood as potent political weapons is as old as the country itself. Donald Trump is just the latest practitioner of this trade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Preston
title: In an Era of Face Masks, We’re All a Little More Face Blind
description: Your brain’s powers of facial recognition are going to need some time to get used to the coverings we’re wearing to keep each other healthy.
content: We’re all getting used to face masks, either wearing them or figuring out who we’re looking at. They can even trip up those of us who are experts in faces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Apple’s App War Needs Peace
description: Changes to Apple’s app store could make developers’ lives — and our smartphones — better.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Boys State, Girls State and the Political Life
description: Readers talk about their formative experiences at Boys State and Girls State in the 1950s. Also: The end of TV listings; college athletes deserve pay; chronic illness; challenges in gardening.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney and Shane Goldmacher
title: Facing national unrest, Biden confronts both a challenge and an opportunity.
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr faces a crosscurrent of pressures as protests continue to batter Portland, Ore., and Kenosha, Wis. On one side is President Trump, who is trying to blame Mr. Biden for the unrest as he presses the theme of his convention — remember that? It was last week — that a Biden presidency would lead to disorder and crime. He has repeatedly used false claims to portray Mr. Biden as anti-law enforcement.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr faces a crosscurrent of pressures as protests continue to batter Portland, Ore., and Kenosha, Wis. On one side is President Trump, who is trying to blame Mr. Biden for the unrest as he presses the theme of his convention — remember that? It was last week — that a Biden presidency would lead to disorder and crime. He has repeatedly used false claims to portray Mr. Biden as anti-law enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Smith
title: Hockey’s Fights and Handshakes? Not Exactly Socially Distant
description: Home-ice advantage is gone and fans are locked out, but the games in Toronto and Edmonton still feel like playoff hockey.
content: As the clock ran out on their season in Edmonton, the desperate Chicago Blackhawks did what any team would: They crowded the net, looking for an opening, anything. Stopped short, the Blackhawks could only watch as the victorious Vegas Golden Knights hugged out their five-game series win. Both teams then removed the gloves they had been wearing, lining up for the handshakes that hockey tradition demands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriel Debenedetti
title: How Has Donald Trump Survived?
description: Michael S. Schmidt’s “Donald Trump v. the United States” describes the uncomfortable tenures of two influential White House figures.
content: DONALD TRUMP V. THE UNITED STATESInside the Struggle to Stop a PresidentBy Michael S. Schmidt
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Learn About ‘The Politics of the Potato’
description: A new book dives into the history, including the ties to government food policies in Europe, the United States and elsewhere.
content: The potato, as Rebecca Earle, the author of “Feeding the People,” this detailed, scholarly survey, puts it, is “a fantastically successful global food stuff.” It was all but unknown before the 16th century outside its native Andean region, where it had been appreciated for some 10,000 years. Healthful, tasty and economical, it has been tied to government food policies in Europe, the United States and elsewhere, notably for nourishing workers. Issues of class, colonialism, commercial agriculture, peasant farming and government regulation versus freedom of choice are clearly (and densely) laid out and documented. A handful of recipes includes one from The New York Times in 1943 for a layered, jellied meat and potato loaf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and José Bautista
title: ‘Here We Go Again’: A Second Virus Wave Grips Spain
description: The coronavirus is spreading much faster in Spain than anywhere else in Europe. After a relative lull during the summer, experts fear it signals a new surge across the continent.
content: MÁLAGA, Spain — At midday on Sunday, there were 31 patients inside the main coronavirus treatment center in Málaga, the city with the fastest-rising infection rate in southern Spain. At 12:15 p.m., the 32nd arrived in an ambulance. Half an hour later came number 33.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Ron Jeremy Is Charged With Sexually Assaulting 13 More Women
description: The new charges brought by the Los Angeles County District Attorney’s office against the pornographic film star bring the total number of alleged victims to 17.
content: The pornographic film star Ron Jeremy has been charged with sexually assaulting 13 more women, the Los Angeles County District Attorney’s office said on Monday, bringing the total number of alleged victims to 17.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Rejecting Censorship of His Book, a French Star Economist Stands Up to China
description: Thomas Piketty, the renowned economist, refused Chinese demands that he cut parts of his book if he wanted it published on the mainland.
content: PARIS — With his in-depth critique of Western capitalism, detailed in a 700-page book that enjoyed record sales in 2014, France’s rock-star economist Thomas Piketty was well regarded by Chinese leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: An Upper East Side Market With Space to Move
description: This new branch of Butterfield Market have opened up the former Dean & DeLuca location in part to observe social distancing.
content: The spacious former Dean & DeLuca on the Upper East Side has now become a branch of Butterfield Market, a store that has been on Lexington Avenue since 1915. The owners, Evan and Joelle Obsatz, and their father, Alan Obsatz, have added features like a sushi counter, an appetizing department and a pizzeria, which are not in the original. They also opened up the white-tiled space, with fewer counters clogging central aisles, in part to observe social distancing and also for a more expansive look. The new market sells produce, groceries, dairy, baked goods and, soon, meat and seafood. But there is a greater emphasis on prepared food to meet a demand that the owners recognize as having become more necessary with the pandemic. They are also geared up for home delivery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Journalist Quits Kenosha Paper in Protest of Its Jacob Blake Rally Coverage
description: Daniel Thompson, an editor at The Kenosha News, resigned over a headline that highlighted a speaker who made a threat during a peaceful protest.
content: A journalist resigned on Saturday from his job at The Kenosha News after objecting to the headline of an article that chronicled a rally in support of Jacob Blake, a Black man who was shot seven times in the back by a white Kenosha police officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: What’s It Like to Live With a Beauty Queen? Ask Miss Universe, She Rooms With Miss USA
description: The two pageant winners traditionally share a New York apartment, but that has taken on new meaning in the pandemic, since neither can travel for her usual appearances.
content: When Zozibini Tunzi moved into the Midtown apartment where Cheslie Kryst was living last December, some roommate tension might have been expected.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Turmoil in Portland and Kenosha
description: Readers write that President Trump is stoking fear for his political advantage.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Jeffrey Gettleman
title: India’s Economy Shrank Nearly 24 Percent Last Quarter
description: It’s the biggest decline of any major economy. Economists say once the impact on the country’s vast “informal” work force is taken into account, the damage might be even worse.
content: NEW DELHI — The Indian economy contracted by 23.9 percent in the second quarter, the most drastic fall in decades, as lockdown restrictions meant to contain the spread of the coronavirus wiped out jobs and businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: A Quick Virus Test? Sure, If You Can Afford It
description: Standard tests in New York City can take days. Wealthier people are turning to concierge services and small laboratories to get results in as little as 24 hours.
content: As major laboratories struggle to meet surging demand for coronavirus tests, wealthier people and others in privileged professions are avoiding long waits for results — anywhere from four days to more than two weeks in New York City — by skipping the lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Buchanan, Lazaro Gamio and Alicia Parlapiano
title: Will You Have Enough Time to Vote by Mail in Your State?
description: Yes, but in 35 states, deadlines to request a ballot are so close to Election Day that it’s risky to procrastinate.
content: Yes, but in 35 states, deadlines to request a ballot are so close to Election Day that it’s risky to procrastinate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby and Lisa Waananen Jones
title: U.S. Coronavirus Rates Are Rising Fast Among Children
description: Young children seem to catch and transmit the virus less, but rising numbers of cases, hospitalizations and deaths show they are increasingly affected.
content: Young children seem to catch and transmit the virus less, but rising numbers of cases, hospitalizations and deaths show they are increasingly affected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronica Penney
title: Think You’re Making Good Climate Choices? Take This Mini-Quiz
description: Most Americans don’t have the information they need to effectively reduce their greenhouse gas emissions, according to new research. You might be one of them.
content: Most Americans don’t have the information they need to effectively reduce their greenhouse gas emissions, according to new research. You might be one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1 Million in California
description: A hillside house in Oakland, a midcentury-modern home built by Joseph Eichler in Los Angeles and a one-bedroom cottage in Laguna Beach.
content: A hillside house in Oakland, a midcentury-modern home built by Joseph Eichler in Los Angeles and a one-bedroom cottage in Laguna Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Kite Drags 3-Year-Old Girl Into the Sky
description: Powerful winds swept a young girl into the air after she became entangled in the kite’s tail during a festival in Taiwan. The girl landed safely.
content: Powerful winds swept a young girl into the air after she became entangled in the kite’s tail during a festival in Taiwan. The girl landed safely.

author: By The New York Times
title: Watch Full Video: Biden Delivers Speech in Pittsburgh
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign said the speech would “lay out a core question voters face in this election: Are you safe in Donald Trump’s America?”
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign said the speech would “lay out a core question voters face in this election: Are you safe in Donald Trump’s America?”
